title: BofA Global Research moves Fed rate cut forecast to October from December
content: Bank of America (BofA) Global Research has advanced its forecast for the next Federal Reserve interest rate cut from December to October 2025, citing signs of a softening labor market. The U.S. government shutdown has delayed key economic data, complicating the Fed’s decision-making. BofA warns of the risk of “over-easing” monetary policy. Investors now overwhelmingly expect rate cuts in October and December.

title: Stocks mixed, gold hits record as US government shuts down
content: Financial markets saw mixed performance amid the U.S. government shutdown, which has put uncertainty on key economic releases. U.S. stock futures and the dollar dipped, while gold surged to a record high, fueled by growing expectations of a Federal Reserve rate cut. Approximately 750,000 federal workers are furloughed, and the shutdown is estimated to cost the government ~$400 million per day.

title: Dow, S&P 500 manage record closing highs; Nasdaq falls in volatile session
content: In a volatile session, both the Dow Jones and S&P 500 posted record closing highs, while the Nasdaq lagged. The rally was underpinned by rate-cut expectations even as the U.S. government shutdown prolonged. The nonfarm payrolls report for September was not published due to the shutdown, increasing reliance on alternate economic indicators.

title: Wall Street closes with records as tech support offsets labor, shutdown uncertainties
content: Wall Street’s main indexes closed at record highs, aided by strength in the tech sector, even as investors weighed weak private labor market data and the ongoing U.S. government shutdown. The Dow rose ~0.17%, the S&P 500 ~0.06%, and Nasdaq ~0.39%. The absence of official employment data increased speculation about timing and magnitude of future rate cuts.

title: US equity funds see sharp weekly inflows on rate cut hopes
content: Investors poured a net $36.41 billion into U.S. equity funds in the week to October 1, driven by renewed expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts. Large-cap funds were the main beneficiaries, while small- and mid-cap segments saw modest outflows. Bond funds saw some net sales as yields adjusted.

title: Global banking climate alliance folds four years after launch
content: The Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), created to help align banking with climate goals, has disbanded after four years. The collapse followed withdrawals from many key member banks, political pressures, and legal risks. Some institutions may still use the frameworks for climate risk, but the disbandment signals challenges for coordinated green finance in the current geopolitical climate.

title: Gulf sovereign wealth funds defy lower oil prices to top global investment
content: Despite a decline in oil prices, Gulf sovereign wealth funds remained among the world’s most active investors in 2025. In the first nine months, they deployed $56.3 billion, representing ~40 % of global sovereign fund activity. Saudi Arabia’s PIF led with a $55 billion acquisition of Electronic Arts, while other Gulf funds continued diversified investing both domestically and internationally.

title: AI will trigger financial calamity. It'll also remake world.
content: This Washington Post piece explores the dual nature of AI: while it could reshape industries and productivity, it also carries systemic financial risks. Complex financing loops among tech firms, high valuations, and self-reinforcing capital flows draw parallels to the dot-com bubble. The article warns of opacity in earnings and potential collapse scenarios, even amid enthusiasm for transformative potential.

title: UK's FTSE 100 share index closes at record high as AstraZeneca becomes London's biggest stock again
content: On October 1, the UK’s FTSE 100 closed at a record high of ~9,446 points. AstraZeneca surged ~11%, regaining status as the largest firm on the London Stock Exchange, surpassing HSBC. The rally came amid easing concerns over proposed U.S. import tariffs on branded drugs. Meanwhile, UK house prices rose 0.5% in September, and eurozone inflation edged up to 2.2%.

title: Israel and Hamas
content: Israel and Hamas signaled a readiness to move forward with parts of President Trump’s cease-fire plan in what many hoped would lead to a diplomatic breakthrough, but significant gaps will need to be negotiated to bring an end to the war in Gaza
